channel.title: Which do you prefer, Awt or Swing?
channel.description: I personally like awt :) more backwards compatibility, and works better with threads.

item.title: Which do you prefer, Awt or Swing?
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:27, topic:32514”]“SWT is not comparable to swing in any way shape or form, swing is far more flexible and powerful, swt provides limited functionality and only provides native peers of the OS really, making any sort of custom component in swt is a bitch and a half due to its design. SWT is more along the lines of AWT.”
Which is why a lot of higher scaled programs are written in SWT ;[/quote]
Exactly =]

item.title: Which do you prefer, Awt or Swing?
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

I much prefer Swing to SWT. Swing gives a lot more power. It is possible to make amazing GUIs with Swing, if a little ‘know-how’ is applied.

Notice how alot of methods in Swing are protected? They are like that for a reason. Who said we weren’t allowed to make our own subclasses of swing? Animated ‘JTabbedPanes’, custom ‘JButtons’ - even transparent JPanels.
Given a decent programmer and some imagination, the possibilities of Swing are endless.

Read full topic
item.source: Which do you prefer, Awt or Swing?

item.title: Which do you prefer, Awt or Swing?
item.dc:creator: @sup000 sup000
item.description:
@sup000 wrote:

i remembered these wise words from another post

[quote=“Sean, post:34, topic:11367”][quote author=ruler link=topic=16905.msg194743#msg194743 date=1156849789]
Sean, i do know the swing api. However i am using swt now.
Oddly i can write guis in swt faster than swing however i dont know the swt api fully yet.
[/quote]

The double buffering has nothing to do with speed for #1.

(taken from)

(20:54:46) (ruler) most things in swing are double buffered
(20:54:49) (ruler) bc swing is so slow
(20:54:53) (ruler) it would flicker like crazy
(20:54:59) (ruler) if not double buffered

Which shows you have no idea why it is double buffered.

(20:55:16) (WhiteCastle) Plus Swing is really buggy.

Just retarded.

SWT is not comparable to swing in any way shape or form, swing is far more flexible and powerful, swt provides limited functionality and only provides native peers of the OS really, making any sort of custom component in swt is a bitch and a half due to its design. SWT is more along the lines of AWT.

Swing is a beast of an api, alot of the developers that use it dont fully understand it, but swing is INCREDIBLY powerful - which is why it also takes work to understand.[/quote]

Read full topic
item.source: Which do you prefer, Awt or Swing?

item.title: Which do you prefer, Awt or Swing?
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Java was designed primarily with security and cross platformability in mind. It wasn’t meant to include GUIs and certainly isn’t speed oriented. Thats why I like awt - swing is too slow.

Read full topic

item.title: Which do you prefer, Awt or Swing?
item.dc:creator: @RLN RLN
item.description:
@RLN wrote:

awt is faster, but swing has more components. awt will look different depending what os you are on because it uses jni. swing will look generally the same on all os’. It depends what you would like to do, if you need certain components which awt does not provide then you will have to create your own, or go with swing. I personally prefer awt for most things - performance > aesthetics

Read full topic
item.source: Which do you prefer, Awt or Swing?
